French PM Lecornu unveils broadly unchanged government
subhed: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu appointed a new finance minister and a replacement for himself as defense minister, but his new government is largely identical to the one that collapsed less than a month ago.

title: Republicans warn of pain ahead as US shutdown faces its second week
subhed: Most federal operations remain shuttered, with no signs of ending, as Republicans and Democrats continue to disagree about expiring Obamacare health subsidies. The country's last government shutdown in 2018 cost the US economy an estimated $11 billion.

title: The EAT-'Lancet' commission outlines a fairer global diet for feeding the planet sustainably
subhed: A study published on Friday in 'The Lancet' finds that food systems are a major driver of environmental degradation, rising chronic disease and growing inequality. The report calls for a shift toward less meat-heavy diets and a more equitable distribution of value along the food chain.

title: Sweden's new list of 'cultural values' sparks controversy
subhed: Pippi Longstocking, Ikea, Bergman… In early September, Sweden's conservative government unveiled a list aimed at defining a 'common frame of reference' to promote the integration of foreigners. The opposition has condemned the project's nostalgic vision.

title: The making of the Agnès b. cardigan
subhed: Since its creation in 1979, the Agnès b. snap cardigan has sold more than two million pieces. Functional and timeless, it has been produced in more than 150 colors and 40 versions, immortalized by world-renowned photographers and even exhibited in museums.

title: AI's appetite for power could trigger electricity shortages in the US
subhed: Electricity demand in the US is projected to rise by 25% by 2030 due to the growing use of artificial intelligence. Yet, the power grid is struggling to keep pace, and most of the electricity consumed will continue to be generated from fossil fuels.

title: In Morocco, 'The regime made a mistake in thinking that by offering the people sporting events, they would forget their problems'
subhed: As Morocco's Gen Z takes to the streets, King Mohammed VI no longer has a political force capable of offering an 'alternative solution,' says researcher Thierry Desrues in an interview with Le Monde.
